text: This wonderfully aromatic beer ticks all my boxes! The after taste is the best of any beer.
UPDATED: MAR 23, 2017 Aroma agradável, cor âmbar e espuma densa e duradoura. Sabor com leve amargor e paladar suave.
OK for a low alcohol beer if youre driving, but not much else. No aroma to sniff of. Nice dry finish
500ml bottle pours a brown color with a bit of head. Noticeable low alcohol. Some mild hop bitterness overpowers

330ml bottle. Toasted hazelnuts, toffee, apple, toast. Thin, far too carbonated body. The carbonation takes over the flavour a bit too. Honestly a bit of a mess. As an Englishman, I find it outrageous that this is rated higher than bitters back home, despite being completely out of style and really not that pleasant. Perhaps the Kiwi palate is more easily pleased. Hard pass.

500ml bottle BB 1/6/2016 (though I dont think this was correct as I got no trace of oxidation).
Hoppy malty aroma.
Slightly hazy light brown color with slight head.
Good bitterness up front with a slight burnt roasted character at the back.
At 3.7%, an excellent session beer.

[8263-20160514] Tap. Toasted celery grains aroma. Clear, bright orange body with a long-lasting creamy white head. Bitter grainy green pepper vegetable flavour has a hint of peanuts. Medium body. Good, odd at first. (7/4/8/4/15) 3.8
(@ Tonic, Dunedin, NZ)

2016-05-14. Crisp dark amber body with a nice beige head and lace. 3+ Aroma is surprisingly dry, toasty malt with some grassy straw like qualities to it. Flavour is malt forward, roast malt, light caramel notes. Average bodied palate, good carbonation. Just okay. 6/3-4/6/3/12-13 On tap at Tonic, Dunedin, NZ.

UPDATED: MAY 14, 2016 500 ml bottle bought at YATA in MOKO, Mong Kok.
Looks: Clear amber copper colour; Three-quarter finger head with off-white foam which lasts for 1 minute; Very good sticky lacing with fizzy carbonation.

Aroma: Very fragrant and sweet Ale malt, with strong caramel, toffee, pineapple, light passion fruits, grains, floral, strong molasses, biscuits, lemon and grass.

Taste: Close to light sweet moderate Amber malt, with caramel, strong grains, floral, fair molasses, light bread, strong lemon, fairly strong bitter hops and grass.

Body: Mid to light body. Dry and slick palate.

Mouth Feel: Close to fair Ale maltyness in a pretty slick background. Caramel and strong graininess as base with shades of burnt toast. Very lemony with fairly light sweetness. Biscuity to round. Good!

Hoppiness: Pineapple, passion fruits, floral, lemon and grass in nose. Floral, strong lemon and grass in taste; Bitterness is quite strong for a lasting, medium astringent toasty malty finish.

After Taste: Quite dry. Lemony and bitter to mouth.

Comments: This ones hops has changed from Saaz to Riwaka, so its aroma is pretty tropical fruity and sweet, with toasty grainy Amber malt taste with solid lemon hoppiness. Dont really like its strong graininess, otherwise a very nice and solid Pale Ale. Expensive but still worth the money!
Poured a dark golden colour, lacy, small head. Earthy nose. Mild hop finish but slightly watery.

500ml bottle from Brothers Beer. Clear reddish copper pour with a large, quickly dissipating white head. Nutty aroma with tea and caramel. The flavor has a restrained malty sweetness giving way to a bitter hop finish with a touch of tartness. Lighter bodied and effervescent. Good for what it is!

Pours a dark gold with Spicy and grassy hops on the nose. A hint of biscuits as well. Flavours bring more grassy hops up front with a bit of toast and lingering bitterness that fade away to reveal a nutty finish.

From 500ml bottle that poured an excellent orange gold & lacy with a mild hoppy aroma the taste is all hops but surprisingly quite mild a bit watery but still full of subtle fruit spice malty bitter flavours great session beer
Bottle. Clear dark copper color, small white head. Aroma is fruity, crispy hoppy and malty. Taste is hoppy, malty, sweet suryp notes, hint of orange.

Sampling this little number sitting a top the coromandel peninsula. Very sessionable. Nice biscuity malt, understated hops. Looks great and just goes to show that not all beers need to be be drowning in hoppy bitterness to be good!

I am well used to enjoying this beauty of a session beer from Emersons, especially in-between a few cheeky drams, but on this particular evening a fortnight ago, I was blown away by both the flavour and aroma. The nose was its typical malty-loveliness but this time the flavour was almost like a fragrant floral perfume from the combination of hops. She was beer number 3 from 4 on our evenings tasting yet despite being low abv. , she stole the show. This was from a 2l rigger from Regional wines in Wellington. Pity the taste wasnt of the same fragrance from the next keg.

I did try this beer a couple of times over the years, and today it is a gift from a friend - thanks Greg - with a customised label celebrating the centennial of Scott. Unfortunately I never learned/learnt to appreciate this singular combination of hop bitternesses, finding the aroma and flavour too pungent, perhaps too herbal and metallic. Definitely not my pint of beer.

Tasted 6/2/2014. BB 16 Jul 2014. Poured a clear coppery amber colour (nice colour) with a light tan collar that produced poor to OK lacing. Carbonation low to moderate with medium sized bubbles. Aroma sweetly of alcohol with citrus or piney hops. Taste slightly sweet caramel malt followed by an unusually unsavoury hops bitterness. Light body. Clean but then a long citrus and piney bitter finish. Found this to be not very nice.

On tap @ Emersons. New Zealand holiday 2011-12. Old notes. The aroma has flowery hops. Clear, copper coloured beer with an off-white head. The taste is slightly bitter, bit toasted, has some cookie and the flowery hops.
The head is ok, the body is gold-brown. It smells hoppy, hoparomatic, bitter. The taste is hoparomatic, bitter, fruity, aromatic, nice!

floral aroma golden, amber colour minimal head, medium bitterness, light body, thin feel, average carbonation, short bitter finish.
Nice but lacks depth.

I really loved this beer, described as an anytime refreshing new world ale, I felt this was a beer I could drink anytime. The 3.7% abv means this is a beer that can be drunk all night and the great flavours makes it easy to drink all night.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

cant say im too impressed. didnt get much flavour from this at all, a little hop and a little malt played background to what almost seemed a lagerish theme. not too bad i suppose, and ive never been too keen on the normal bitter style (quite like the esb), but its a bit flavourless for my liking.

Even though my bottle says the best before date is Sep 2013 (6 months away) this bottle has already lost its freshness as had another bottle bought at the same shop (not my regular). The aroma was starting to turn toward the wet cardboard side. Having said that, I soldiered on and drank. The taste was delicious piny resin perfectly supported by top malt session musicians who know how to lay down a sweet unobtrusive groove. Like everybody says, this really does taste bigger than 3.7%. I cant wait to try another (fresh) bottle.

On tap in Dunedin. This is an excellent approximation of an easy drinking English style session Bitter. There are English style hops on the nose and palate and it is smooth and drinkable with a low carbonation. Nice floral hop bitterness. Recommended.

Bottle that Earl brought me from NZ. Thanks! Pours mostly clear amber to orange color with nice white head. Aroma is hops, grass, molasses. Flavor is hops, citrus fruits, malt and honey. Surprisingly full flavor considering the alcohol content. Slightly dry aftertaste.

500mL Bottle. Pours an amber/brown beer. Easy drinking beer from Emersons, you should happily drink this all night. A good balance of malts and hops, with a medium length finish. Not as full of flavour as some of the others in the Emersons range, but still enjoyable.
Great beer,   smooth tasting amber coloured and not high alcohol, so easy to drink a few.

Enjoyable mild session beer as described.  Slight spice and biscuity flavour with this one.  One of those beers that does not provoke a great amount of thought and is best just enjoyed while watching the rugby.
500ml bottle. Pours a dark hazy, malty brown with minimal head. Aroma is caramel, bread, nuts and coffee. Taste is earthy with coffee malt and some toasted bread. Very nice, easy drinking bitter
Very easy drinking beer.  Good body with a soft texture and flavours to boot.  Little thin on the palate and major drawback is you would need to drinks lots of this to get your buzz on!
Bottle. This was not the greatest from emersons, my main issue was its over carbonation. Not the tastiest beer either.
Bottled. Amber colour with thin head. Smells hops. Tastes light sweeterness, with a light bitter finish.

Scrumptious easy drinking bitter. Pours a copper brown color. The malty and caramel characters dominate. Solid beer!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

(bottle) Poured slightly hazy copper coloured with a ridiculous amount of head (even carefully poured). Aroma is a pleasant malty caramel with orange hints. Light body, overly fizzy. Flavour is straightforward malt to hops bitter. Its no frills, not much else going on, but decent quality. Overall a no frills basic but reasonable beer.
Deep copper color. Subtle malty backbone with some soft hoppy notes. A bit heavy for a bitter but enjoyable.

Copper-gold in colour underneath a white head that thins and subsides over time. Smells brassy and of orange peel. Theres also a cheesy note (not a bad thing. It makes this beer versatile and ideally adaptable). Theres sweet mandarin and other juicy fruits on the first impression. Then the flavours settle on the tongue and spread into a soft bitterness that is grounded mainly in sweet fruits.  Becomes citrus and astringent and is quite a tasty little critter. I like that it is 3.7%. It makes it ideally suited for a session bitter (where there is no Twisted Hop Golding of course).

500ml bottle. Clear, light amber pour with an off-white head moderate lace. Light malt and citrus hop nose. Medium-light body and moderate carbonation. Caramel, almonds, pine, biscuit, with some lemon tartness near the end. Finish is short and slightly bitter. Sessionable, but a bit weak on body.

Bottled. An amber beer with a thin beige head. The aroma has notes of caramel and malt as well as a light note of hops. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt and caramel as well as a light touch of straw.

Bottle 500ml. Very nice bitter. Aromas of caramel, grain, cherries, and nuts. Taste is sweet, with light bitterness, and good length. Palate is velvety, and medium bodied. Amber, with a thin frothy head.

Jug at the Southern Cross.  My go-to session ale.  Rich amber-light-copper colour, small white head.  Firm hop aroma of earthy, spicy, floral goodness.  Biscuity, caramel malt, fruity ale flavour, balancing hop bitterness.  Delightfully refreshing and drinkable.

500ml bottle. Low ABV for a bitter but it carries it well. Full creamy rich beige head with good lacing on the glass. Mild copper colour with some caramel aromas covering some grapefruit, all in all pretty good. Zingy in the mouth with a smoothness that makes it go down easy.

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2012 Pours a light amber with a small white head. Aromas of  floral hops with underlying tones of sweet malts. Begins with some good floral hops masked by the sweet toffee like malts and gradually follows through with a darker, more toasty malt characteristic. Pretty decent beer for 3.7 ABV. Very thin palate is a disappointment. Super easy, flavoursome drinking though

From a 500ml bottle on 17/1/2011. Has a distinct floral, perfumey, malty, fruity aroma. Flavours are fruit, honey and sweet malt, with some wine like notes. Has along finish with a slightly sour bitterness. Has quite a light body. Has masses of character for a beer that only 3.7%. A very good bitter.

Pours dark amber with a small head.
Nose shows spicy, herbaceous and floral hops in abundance. Underneath is plenty of sweet malt with toffee characters.
Similar flavours although the hops fade a little, revealing nutty, toasty malt, along with the aforementioned toffee.
Good moderate carbonation works well, although the body seems a bit watery.

This is top flight low ABV beer and surely Australasias best beer under 4%. Very classic and understated. Nice floral lift on the nose which follows nicely in the palate with a little herbaly zing. malts are low key but of the very accessible, caramel kind. Would love a touch more oomph but this would be contary to style.

500ml bottle, tulip glass.  Clear deep copper hue, off white thick creamy head quickly diminishes to a thin creamy head, very good lacing.  Wonderful marmalade aromas, fruity, spicy, and caramel malty.  Nice, easy-drinking flavour and palate - mild to moderate malty fruity sweet, moderate bitter, slight citrus sour, soft carbonation, medium body, dry astringent finish.   Overall fairly nice easy to drink beer, good despite its lack of complexity.
Beautiful ruby red colour with light citrus flavours.  Sudsy and fizzy in taste.  Good one indeed.

500 ml bottle

Aroma: Malts and yeast, fairly indistinctive.

Appearance: yellowish brown, clear with adequate  toffee coloured head and good lacing.

Taste: Near lambic like sourness, bitterness is fairly well pronounced, no trace of sweetness.

Palate: body is a bit thin as is texture, carbonation is soft while finish is long and mellow with a trace of astringency.

Overall:  Not a beer to write home about. Id choose it over most macrobrews down here but it just does not make much of an impression.

Bottle. Clear amber, 1/2 cm beige head. Savoury aroma floral and grassy hops with earth and caramel underneath. Delicate mouthfeel. A little malt sweetness with some fruit and hop firmness. Medium length mild bitter finish. A little too much fizz. Probably would be very good on tap. As it is, its a pretty good bottled bitter and very pleasant, easy-going drop. I have to admit I was hoping for more from Emersons here, but great bitter is elusive.

Aroma of sweet caramel, toffee malts along with some floral hops. Clear amber colour with a nice head. Sweetish  caramel, toffee malts  alongside some fruity hops. Very smooth on the palate with a mild bitterness. Fantastic session ale.
Ah Bookie, my perennial favourate.  Brownish amber, with white head.  Caramel malt with a slight hop aroma.  Flavour is bready, caramel malt with a smooth, bitter hop finish.

Boy oh boy, have I waited a long time to try this. I didnt even know it was in the country, I just walked into Slowbeer and there it was. Sweet. Quite a lot of weirdness initially (rubber, higher alcohols??) which eventually blows off. Subtle hop in that edgy, tropical, NZ way, some blackberry esters and loads of crystal malt. Mouthfeel is simultaneously creamy and quite fizzy. Your palate eventually adjusts to the huge crystal content and then you realise theres actually good base malt character behind it. A touch grainy and roasty, with a subtly minerally finish. Gets a whole lot more interesting as you drink it, and has bucketloads of flavour for 3.7%.

Bottle. Pours a light mahogany with Dense coffee coloured head disappears slowly leaving nice lacing. Citrus and pine aromas of kiwi hops nicely balanced by sweet malt and caramel. Palate is on the thin side but seems to work for this beer. Flavours of sweet malt and caramel once again nicely balanced by floral hops. Finish is nicely bitter. Great session beer. Would happily drink this beer all day.

Creamy good head on top a light red/brown pour near amber aroma fruit mix malt vanilla caramel nut flavour citrus caramel plesant bitter,nut love these ales woody note hop fruit flavours are morishing to the finish with the added malt tastes slight clash in flavours.
nice malty mouthfeel, great hop aroma it just jumps out at you and a really smooth drinker... would love to have this on tap somewhere

Draft at Atlas Beer Cafe in Queenstown.  Pours slightly cloudy copper with an eggshell white head that laces the glass.  Hoppy aroma, with malt and earthy notes.  The flavor opens up more and in addition to the hops, malt, and earth, marmalade sweetens and balances the brew.  Malty, mildly bitter, with a dry finish.  I had quite a few bitters in New Zealand and this was among the best.

Pours clear amber with a small head. nose is quite floral with some mild caramel/toffee malt & slight apricot esters. Palate is rather high in carbonation which lightens up the palate, perhaps not a good thing given its relative light weight, abv etc. Finishes with slight apricot, orange hop notes. Overall a pretty solid bitter given low abv, Suspect it would be really good on draught.
UPDATED: FEB 4, 2011 It is amazing how much flavor can be packed into such a small beer. Plenty of hop flavor, a perfect amount of cara type malts to balance . Plenty of body for a small beer.

On tap.
Pours amber,red,brown with good head.
Aroma fruits,caramel, orange.
Tastes of nice caramel malt balanced with mid bitterness, nice hop flavour with passionfruit,orange and floral coming through.
A well balanced beer.
Draught. Pours a deep amber with a small diminished white head. Caramel, toasted malt, fruit and nuts. This is really well balanced with a smooth crisp finish. Very drinkable.

Ive had this recently on tap at Robbie Burns in Dunedin, and from the bottle with dinner last night. Clear bright oange-amber, off-white frothy head. Lots of fruit in the aroma, tropical fruit, orange. Caramel malt undertones. The palate has delicious aromatic fruity hops married in perfect balance to delicious vienna-style caramel malts. Medium bitterness. Light without being "weak" in any way, very flavourful and satisfying despite the surprisingly low ABV. Another terrific offering from Emersons!
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: UPDATED: JAN 9, 2009 Pours a nice amber colour with a fluffy off white head that dissipates to a thin layer. Fruity passionfruit hop aromas, with a sweetish malt base. Some spice. Flavours flow on the tongue smoothly into each other. Some medium hop bitterness initially, then followed with fruit. Nicely constructed malt base underneath it all. Long finish with a slight bitterness. I could drink this for days, very easy beer.

500mL bottle. Amber/brown. Nice aromas of grassy hops, caramel/roast malt. Some raisin and cherries. Quite complex. 
Flavours of roasted malt and cherries, some bitterness and caramel. Hints of maple syrup, slightly smoky. 
Kind of watery on the palate. Nice, but not amazing.

500mL Bottle. Amber coloured beer with a white head. Very fresh aroma! The initial taste is slightly floral and of caramel malts, with a moderately bitter and finish. This beer is only 3.7% but is very fresh and drinkable. One you could drink all night. Relatively complex though perhaps not as intense as other Emersons Beers but true to its style.

My first from the bottle! Pours a sexy copper with a fluffy white head which stays right to the bottom of the glass. Aroma features melonfruit, a hint of lemony citrus and grainy whole grain malt. On the palate there is ripe melon, tangy grassy hops, a citrus note, a berry fruit/vinious character, sweet nutty malt, a minerally mouthfell leading to an assertive bitter finish.Great beer!

Pint at many and varied, latterly straight from the keg. Typical Kiwi brown to look at. Faint berry dry aroma but such intregue in the mouth for a beer so light. Finally back close to its best with a substantial malt change from recent times. NZs no1 session drop.

(On tap) Clear, warm, amber golden with an off-white head. Lightly nutty nose. Light-bodied yet still with a fairly solid malt base. Notes of caramel and nuts. Short, dry finish. A neat session Bitter. 240108

Ive had this one in New Zealand on my honeymoon. Visited the brewery too.

Bought it from the brewery in a big plastic bottle. Very drinkable bitter.
This is one of my favourite bitters, it has a lovely fruity aroma looks great and tastes awesome, so much flavour packed into 3.7%!
not available in bottles - only in 2 litre flaggons or on tap. a real beaty this one. a true bitter. richards done a fine job with this one.
Dark amberin colour with big white head. Mild hop aroma big mouthful of hop. Is best fresh.
Unfortunately due to living in England I havent had the pleasure for a while but love the hoppy notes and fruity nose on it.  Great session beer and is best fresh.
2 litre pub pet, Regional Wines, Wellington. Fruity and hoppy, delicious past its 3.7% strength. Well done.
On tap in Dunedin.  Excellent session bitter.  Piney hops with a solid malt backing and medium carbonation.  Funkiness of the Saaz was low key.  Must be best on draft at the source.
A really great fruity Bitter. It has a distinct and refreshing berry flavour and is among NewZealands top 10 beers. Surprisingly absent from many of the outets selling other Emersons.
Such an intensely tasty beer, only 3.7%.  Refreshing and crisp.  Beautiful floral aroma.  A real treat!

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2007 Draught at The Malthouse, Wellington.  Clear pale brown. Light aroma of roasty malt. Very light bodied. The crisp bready malt profile nearly allows water to shine through. The hop rate is low, and so is the bitterness. Serving this beer with CO2 pressure probably doesnt help it a lot. A cask serving could have lifted the delicate malt character above the fizz.
Simply the best Bitter sold n New Zealand.  Almost too easy to drink in volume.  Best drunk fresh off tap in Dunedin.  Loses a little condition when bought in flagons elsewhere.

On tap.  Copper coloured beer with a thin white head.  Aroma is hoppy with goldings and somethings else citrusy and spicy.  Orange and spices in the nose as well.  Flavour seems to have a bit of diacetyl underneath a decently malty caramel and spice backbone.

UPDATED: APR 14, 2006 Tasted 14/04/2006.  Good Friday! Fill your own flagon from Regional Wines and Spirits, Wellington.
Faintly reddish-hued gold, off-white head that fades and lingers around the edge. Lowly carbonated. Bright.  Grainy nose with some berry fruit.  Sweet pale and crystal malts dominate the front, followed by a juicy, almost winey, note in the middle and a crisp, mediumly bitter, hop bite to finish.  More winey notes in the lingering aftertaste.  Light medium weight but a good mouthfeel due to the soft carbonation.
The number one "session" beer NZ has to offer in my books, though it can be difficult to get. I recommend Bar Edwards, Newton, for the best, freshest, serving youll get in Wellington.

Simply the finest beer I have tasted.  I love the mix between the fruitiness (reminds me a little of blackberries) as you first taste and the bitterness of the aftertaste.  I could drink it all night (and have done!).

I found this on tap at The Malthouse in Wellington. It has a good copper colour and what looks like to be a low carbonation in the glass. The appearance generally in the glass is one that doesnt make you go woohoo but more than anything this is more to do with the generosity of the barkeeps than the beer itself. The nose has a strong pine resin and some blackberries in the overall aroma. The stated 4% belies the mouthfeel and after a while the flavour is an agreeable beer. I am a bit confused with the combination of hops though, a bit like some restaurants tryig to serve a surf and turf, therefore not traditonal but neither a good combination either. In the long run the effervescence resurfaces to further bring this potentially good beer down to mediocrity.
user_location: Potts Point, New South Wales, AUSTRALIA

text: not as interesting as other emersons beers. the nz saaz aroma is pretty strange, there's some caramel and butterscotch and perennials. decent bitter finish with pickled prune
great malt, toffee, brown bread and kiwi-hop aroma. taste is deep and malty and tangily bitter, but a bit too toffeeish for me.
perfect session beer - distinctive, quaffable, and a great tangy, hoppy aroma and taste.
Delicious

Similar to their IPA.  Very piney and resiney with a nice bite.  A bit less intense than their IPA, but not much in regards to flavour.  Golden amber colour, perfect amount of malt balance and fairly light bodied compared to the flavour.  Emersons has yet to disappoint.
